dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh my gosh, launches! Why are they always such a total nightmare?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh my gosh, launches! Why are they always such a total nightmare?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, I dunno, A. I just read this, um, article that actually says there's a secret to, like, getting them right.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, I dunno, A. I just read this, um, article that actually says there's a secret to, like, getting them right.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: A secret? To not completely, like, self-destructing halfway through? Because, uh, that's usually my experience.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A secret? To not completely, like, self-destructing halfway through? Because, uh, that's usually my experience.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it's all about the initial steps, you know? Like, the foundations of a building. If those are, um, solid, you're good.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it's all about the initial steps, you know? Like, the foundations of a building. If those are, um, solid, you're good.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Indeed, the first steps in laying your foundation will determine whether your project is solid and manageable, or if it will be shaky and wobbly because the beginning was not well-thought-out, causing the entire project to struggle or even collapse. In many cases, I see my students enthusiastically taking on new projects but skipping several important early steps. However, projects are like buildings forget to put one brick at the bottom and the entire construction may weaken down the line.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Foundations, right. So, what's, uh, the very first brick, then, for, like, not failing spectacularly?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Foundations, right. So, what's, uh, the very first brick, then, for, like, not failing spectacularly?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so first, after talking to, um, a bunch of pros, you gotta craft a launch plan. Everyone involved, stakeholders, and, like, a big visible launch.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so first, after talking to, um, a bunch of pros, you gotta craft a launch plan. Everyone involved, stakeholders, and, like, a big visible launch.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Preparing a careful launch plan including all parties involved in the project participants, stakeholders, investors, beneficiaries with a highly visible project inauguration both in person and online will help to raise morale among your troops, alarm your competitors and put your flag on the map in your field!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Visible? So, not just a quiet email, but like, a party? Or, uh, a huge announcement?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Visible? So, not just a quiet email, but like, a party? Or, uh, a huge announcement?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly! In-person, online, it really, um, boosts morale and sends a clear message. Then, you need SMART objectives.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly! In-person, online, it really, um, boosts morale and sends a clear message. Then, you need S M A R T objectives.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Preparing a careful launch plan including all parties involved in the project participants, stakeholders, investors, beneficiaries with a highly visible project inauguration both in person and online will help to raise morale among your troops... Identifying SMART objectives Managers work on objectives according to the SMART (Specific, Measurable, Achievable Relevant, & Time-bound) formula, usually long before launching a project.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, I thought objectives were, uh, pretty much set in stone once you start?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, I thought objectives were, uh, pretty much set in stone once you start?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Nah, you can totally modify 'em, A. The World Project Council actually says you have to adjust for, um, evolving landscapes. And benchmarks within 100 days.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Nah, you can totally modify 'em, A. The World Project Council actually says you have to adjust for, um, evolving landscapes. And benchmarks within one hundred days.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At this point flexibility is key, as our expectations and calculations during the preparation stage might be slightly outdated or need additional adjustments, e.g., setting the first SMART benchmark within 100 days! [The article does not mention the 'World Project Council'.]

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so, like, flexible goals. What about, uh, spotting the bad stuff before it happens?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so, like, flexible goals. What about, uh, spotting the bad stuff before it happens?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's where regular SWOT analyses come in. Denis Waitley, the PRA, they both, um, really stress it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's where regular S W O T analyses come in. Denis Waitley, the P R A, they both, um, really stress it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is important to run a SWOT analysis at regular intervals... Famous strategist Denis Waitley once said: Expect the best, plan for the worst, and prepare to be surprised! [The article does not mention 'the PRA'.]

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: SWOT. Seriously? Isn't that, like, super old school?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: S W O T. Seriously? Isn't that, like, super old school?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's a classic for a reason! And, uh, you need a totally transformed communication strategy post-COVID. More hybrid, less face-to-face.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a classic for a reason! And, uh, you need a totally transformed communication strategy post-COVID. More hybrid, less face-to-face.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the post COVID-19 environment, the entire concept of internal and external strategic communication is undergoing a series of fundamental changes. Traditional team communication has shifted from a face-to-face in-office communication into a hybrid communication mode where many teams, sub-teams and individuals work virtually via various teleconference tools...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, like, all the video calls? Or, uh, some kind of new app for talking?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, like, all the video calls? Or, uh, some kind of new app for talking?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely! Like, ProjectCom, for example, is being tested. And you need an efficient information management system.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely! Like, ProjectCom, for example, is being tested. And you need an efficient information management system.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: External communication is also shifting from reliance on the companys or teams websites to increasingly popular visualizing gadgets, apps, smart-phone-based and social media platforms... Set up an information management system. [The article does not mention 'ProjectCom'.]

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Information management... so, just, like, keeping track of files? Not losing stuff?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Information management... so, just, like, keeping track of files? Not losing stuff?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, way more than that! Identifying needs, preventing software crashes, you know. But then, uh, the most important thing...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, way more than that! Identifying needs, preventing software crashes, you know. But then, uh, the most important thing...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Effective information management is no longer just about keeping track of information, it is also about a whole set of issues that might impact your project, from identifying information needs, cyber security, to software and hardware crashes, problems of cloud storage and information distribution.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah? After all that, what could be, like, more important?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah? After all that, what could be, like, more important?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Inspire your team, A. Harvard Business Review found teams united by common goals are, um, way more productive than just money-driven ones.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Inspire your team, A. Harvard Business Review found teams united by common goals are, um, way more productive than just money-driven ones.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Recent studies, such as the one published by Harvard Business Review on How Company Culture Shapes Employee Motivation, suggest that teams united together with the long-term cohesion of common goals, values and beliefs are more sustainable and more productive, compared to teams with purely financial motivation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So it's not just, like, the fancy plans and tech. It's, uh, the people.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So it's not just, like, the fancy plans and tech. It's, uh, the people.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much, A. Pretty much.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much, A. Pretty much.
